bibl.title: Letter from J.F. Siler to Philip Showalter Hench, September 12, 1950

div1.p: Siler describes Kean's medical condition up to his death and notes that there was a beautiful service followed by burial at Monticello. He discusses Blossom Reed's health and financial situation.

div1.head: Letter from J.F. Siler to Philip Showalter Hench, September 12, 1950
div1.opener:
GORGAS MEMORIAL INSTITUTE
OF
TROPICAL AND PREVENTIVE MEDICINE
INCORPORATED
-----
GORGAS MEMORIAL LABORATORY
EXECUTIVE OFFICES
1835 EYE STREET, NORTHWEST
WASHINGTON 6, D. C.
September 12, 1950
JOSEPH F. SILER
PRESIDENT
MAURICE H. THATCHER
VICE PRESIDENT AND GENERAL COUNSEL
WALTER A. BLOEDORN
SECRETARY
Dr. Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minn
My dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
Many thanks for your letter of September 5th relative to General Kean and
also your letter of September 6th referring to Blossom Reed.

As you know, Gen. Kean had complete retention due to an enlargement of the
prostate. When he went into hospital it was necessary to keep the bladder emptied
by the use of a catheter. I don't know the exact operation that was contemplated
but Col. Kimborough did tell me it would not be possible to remove the prostate
because of the General's age and the condition of his heart. They had planned
some other operation but his condition was such that it could not be completed.
However it is my understanding that they did drain his bladder through suprapubic
operation. Unfortunately he had a stroke and for the last few days was confined
under an oxygen tent. I will look into the matter more completely and after I
have seen Col. Kimborough I will write you more definitely concerning the exact
operative procedure.

I visited Gen. Kean every day or so during his stay in hospital until after
the operation when he was under the oxygen tent and I could only converse with
his nurse concerning him. They had a very beautiful service in the Army Medical
Center Chapel at 11:30 last Thursday and immediately thereafter his body was
taken to Monticello for interment. Mrs. Kean went down with the body and returned
the same night.

Referring to your letter concerning Blossom Reed I am say that I am closely
in touch with her through her brother, General Lawrence Reed. Prior to her
mother's death, Col. Russell had written me concerning Mrs. Reed's condition as
it was his desire to get in touch with the representative of Rockefeller Found-
ation concerning the monthly contribution of $100 given to Mrs. Reed, presumably
by Mr. Rockefeller although his name has never been mentioned. In replying to
Col. Russell I told him Mrs. Reed was still alive and suggested that the same
kind donation be made for another year. I also told him that Blossom Reed had
been to very great expense and had used up all her reserves. I wondered if it
might not be possible for him to advise the representative of Rockefeller Found-
ation of Mrs. Reed's condition and to ask that is Mrs. Reed died it would be
possible to continue the monthly gift for a few months until Blossom could make
her plans for the future. She is more than 65 years of age and it is not pos-
sible for her to work.

GORGAS MEMORIAL INSTITUTE
OF
TROPICAL AND PREVENTIVE MEDICINE
INCORPORATED
-----
GORGAS MEMORIAL LABORATORY

MAURICE H. THATCHER
VICE PRESIDENT AND GENERAL COUNSEL

EXECUTIVE OFFICES
1835 EYE STREET, NORTHWEST
WASHINGTON 6, D. C.

Col. Russell's reply to my letter stated that he had forwarded it to the
representative of Rockefeller Foundation and that he had suggested that special
consideration be given to Blossom in case of Mrs. Reed's death.

I mentioned the matter to Gen. Lawrence Reed some time ago and he told me
that Blossom had not heard from the Chase National Bank subsequent to her mother's
death concerning continuation of the donation.

Concerning the monthly payment made by the Walter Reed Memorial Association
I should like to say that this payment amounts to approximately $84 and the mem-
bers of the Board of Directors of the organization have already made arrangements
for continuing this same payment to Blossom Reed. As a matter of fact I arranged
with the bank to give her the extra $50 payment for the month in which her mother
died.

Now for the latest information concerning Blossom. As you know she has had
a number of emotional upsets and on two occasions it was necessary for her to be
placed in hospital for a considerable period of time. A few days ago General Reed
called me up and stated that his sister was in the midst of another of these attacks.
She was brought down to Walter Reed for care and treatment. I came down the fol-
lowing morning and had a conference with the Chief of Psychiatric Service concerning
her. She is getting along all right and we are in hopes that it will not be nec-
essary to transfer her to St. Elizabeth's as it was during her last attack. I
thank that her present condition accounts for her writing you such a letter as she
did. The “nest egg” that she spoke of presumably is the $84 a month that she gets
from the Walter Reed Memorial Association.

I will have a conference with her brother in the near future concerning some
of the other matters referred to in your letter and will advise you more fully
a little later.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, J. F. Siler
Col., (MC), U.S.A., Retired jfs k
